title: Creditor did not properly serve me with a summons to appear in court and argue my side of the case, bank levy followed.
question: Creditor did not properly serve me with a summons to appear in court and argue my side of the case, I want to file a Motion to Vacate the Default Judgment and stop bank levy.
answers:
There is no basic form (see blog below) to set aside a default judgment, so this is something you may want to leave to an experienced collection defense attorney. Without knowing when the default judgment was entered against you and if a copy of it was served on you after entry and any other contacts and documents that you have had with the Plaintiff's law firm about this case, there is no way to advise which statute applies. For instance, if it has been more than two years since the default judgment was entered, then no statute applies, and the legal basis to set aside the default would be Common Law principles of Due Process and the Constitutional requirements for Due Process.

You are correct that you will need to file a Motion to Set Aside Default and Vacate Default Judgment. If you were never served, you should make the motion pursuant to Code of Civil Procedure section 473.5.

You don't indicate how long ago the default judgment was entered.

“When service of a summons has not resulted in actual notice to a party in time to defend the action and a default or default judgment has been entered against him or her in the action, he or she may serve and file a notice of motion to set aside the default or default judgment and for leave to defend the action.” (California Code of Civil Procedure § 473.5(a). )

The motion must be served within the earlier of two years after entry of a default judgment against him or her; or 180 days after service on him or her of a written notice that the default or default judgment has been entered.

The moving party should submit a sworn declaration as to when he or she first learned of this action, whether he or she was ever served with the summons or complaint in the action, and whether he or she ever received notice of entry of default.

I agree. I strongly suggest bringing an attorney in at this point; it's easy to make a mistake, miss an essential court deadline, or otherwise prejudice your chances of getting the default vacated.

It looks like you have enough research to know what to do. However, doing this on your own may be difficult because filing a Motion to Vacate can be a complicated process.

An attorney with experience in debt collection can definitely file a Motion to Vacate for you. I have included a link to a site with some information on filing a Motion to Vacate but I recommend hiring a competent attorney with debt collection experience.
